key_points: Twitter admits its algorithm amplifies more tweets from right-wing politicians and news outlets than from left-wing sources.
The study examined tweets from elected officials in seven countries and political content from U.S. news organizations like Fox News, the New York Times, and BuzzFeed.
Research showed that in six out of seven countries, right-leaning tweets were more amplified, with Canada and the UK showing significant discrepancies.
The study found that Twitter's algorithmic "Home" timeline led to more amplification of political tweets than the chronological timeline.
Twitter stated it is unclear why its algorithm produced these results and suggested the algorithm might need changes.
Rumman Chowdhury and Luca Belli emphasized the need for further analysis to understand and possibly adjust the algorithm.
Twitter plans to make its research available to external researchers and is preparing to allow broader access to its data.
The move is seen as putting pressure on Facebook to also share research, especially in light of recent controversies.
Twitter aims to balance privacy and accountability in its approach to algorithmic transparency.
